data.title: 5.4 PREVIEW 6/7- ISSUES
data.body:
OS: Windows 7 64bit
    Build: as shipped on github
    Version Number: 5.4 Preview build 143/151
    Templates: Blank.cpp from engine folder
    System:i7 3770, 16 GB, GTX 680
    Driver: 384.94


#  preview 6/7
## [Environment Probe] - Bake problem/Others
I dont know how many times i must report this, but nothing is change with this problem from release to release.. Environment probe is broken, both from the misc and from new entity component, etc....

##  In preview 6 probe from new entity component,etc does not update things when something is changed in your scene. [https://i.imgur.com/Dxd5eWH.gif](https://i.imgur.com/Dxd5eWH.gif)


## Also as you can see it does not apply ambient to objects in reflection with the second, third, etc. bake that they got from the first bake. In engine version 3.4-3.8 second bake of probe apply ambient to objects in reflection, without this everything is black in reflections and it shouldnt be like that.

## Here is another gif that show what will happen if you turn off sun and bake just skylight, reflections is black, this is the problem... [https://i.imgur.com/0EytLgg.gif](https://i.imgur.com/0EytLgg.gif)

## Also in preview 6 probe through misc missing size indicator + it stop automatically add cubemap to slot with warning " Schedule "Cubemap texgen schedule" Failed on item "Cubemap texgen scheduleitem" and you need to add cubemap in slot manually

data.title: Introduced non-destructive means of adding additional projects to repository
data.body:
In the support of legacy game dlls, CMake is currently configured to add all subdirectories in <root>/Code that begin with "Game".  This PR would allow users to add any subdirectory instead by utilizing <root>/Code/CMakeLists.txt.

The files committed in this PR are current to the 5.4 preview.

data.title: Rigidbodies occasionally stay in sleep state (5.4 preview)
data.body:
If you press the Enable Physics/AI button or play the game in sandbox to simulate physics, rigidbody simulated object might not simulate at all even when it's clearly in the air.

As soon as you hit the rigidbody in game, it starts falling down like expected, which suggests that said object is in some sort of sleep state when the physics simulation begins.

This didn't happen in 5.3.4. Repro in 5.4 preview sandbox: open sidescroller template, move one cube into air, hit Enable Physics/AI button on/off, then move cube slightly and try again, it will probably not simulate it anymore. If one reloads the level, it again works for the first try.

data.title: Physics issues when Wind enabled (5.3.4 & 5.4 preview)
data.body:
As soon as you put any value in Wind Vector (even 0.001, 0, 0), rigidbody start acting oddly.

For example, if you put default primitive cube from template to have 1.0 mass, it flies up to the sky immediately when you hit play or simulate physics in editor. Anything below 8.0 mass starts physics objects to move upward.

This seem to be somehow related to the rigidbody density. If I set density manually for the cube and put 1.0 for density, cube floats in the air, which could be explained if CE assumes that the density of air is 1.0 kg/m^3.

Since the cube is 1m x 1m x 1m = 1m^3, 1.0kg in mass should equal 1.0 density but that doesn't happen now. 1kg in mass clearly flies the object to the sky, same with 5.0 in mass, where 1.0 in density floats the box in the air (doesn't move down or up) and 5.0 clearly falls down like it should.

There could be many things going wrong here, but it seems like automatically calculated density is one. Even if your paper box would weigh 100 grams, it shouldn't fly into sky.

And like mentioned in the beginning, this happens when you have Wind setup, if you put 0,0,0 as wind vector, gravity works like you'd expect.

data.title: 5.4 template performance issue
data.body:
log says "animation-queue" entries animation overflow. could cause serious performance issues.  
Strange thing is it runs smooth in game mode(game executable). 
It only happens in the editor.   
I think it has something to do with character controller. 
characterController->addVelocity only affects rotation not position,, position changes happens very slowly in the editor where as in the game mode it works.

data.title: Asset browser does not show all items sometimes.
Sandbox locks up when import dialog opens and object is being dragged into the level.
data.body: When you import for example an fbx file, the dialog that asks you what you want to import from that fbx file sometimes takes a few seconds to show up. If you drag an object, for example a mesh into the level, the dialog will show up, while your still dragging in the mesh, and so Sandbox will lock. This can be overcome by pressing escape.

data.title: 5.3.3 SDKs downloaded for 5.4.0_preview
data.body:
Both on Windows and on Linux the 5.3.3 SDKs are downloaded instead of the 5.4.0_preview SDKs.

```
C:\Users\....>download_skds.exe
Downloading: CRYENGINE_v5.3.3_SDKs.zip Bytes: 595609109
 595609109  [100.0]%
Extracting 50439 files to:"Code/SDKs"
```

Given the existence of the 5.4.0 preview SDK zip file on the release page, I assume that is the one that should be downloaded.

data.title: !BE (System) Translate x, y for mousewheel events
data.body:
WM_MOUSEWHEEL will give x and y relative to the upper left corner of the screen (see https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms645617(v=vs.85).aspx).
ScreenToClient is needed to translate these x/y values to those relative to the application (to be consistent with the other mouse events)

data.title: No "vulgar" games?
data.body:
> use the CryEngine for the development of any Games which are harmful, abusive, racially or ethnically offensive, vulgar, sexually explicit, defamatory, infringing, invasive of personal privacy or publicity rights, or in a reasonable person's view, objectionable;

I mean by all means adhere to your own discretionary license, but what exactly do you consider "Vulgar"? Most CoD-type AAA games would fall under this clause. What about historically accurate games about slave trade? What about games like GTA?

What do you consider a "reasonable person"? Is that legally binding? I know several people that would find Far Cry to be incredibly indoctrinating to children given their personal views. Are they "unreasonable"?

Just curious as this clause cuts out a lot of potential customers and certainly limits my ability to utilize the engine.

data.title: !R (CryPluginManager) Allow specifying (un)load priority.
data.body:
So, since schematyc insisted on being loaded and unloaded in a very specific order, I looked into prototyping a plugin load/unload priority mechanism lol, if you want a read/my rudimentary implementation idea;

## [General Idea]
I opted to leave the ordering mostly to the coders, whilst initially separating system plugins from user (default) plugins, but allowing flexibility to override if need be.
Basically I just isolated the Initialize() method for the plugins away from the class instantiation, the plugins initialize in the order they arrive, but the ICryPlugin interface method to Initialize() is called in the order of the ICryPlugin Priorities (order of arrival if matching priority).

## [Implementation]
Simply added a couple int16s (m_loadPriority/m_unloadPriority) to the ICryPlugin class as protected friends to CryPluginManager.
Load/Unload creates a temp vector sorted by these values.

## [Details (Load)]
During load a temporary **vector<IcryPlugin*> containerPtrs** is created.
A range loop iterates over **m_pluginContainer**(s ?) and pushes a pointer into **containerPtrs** for each element.
Quick call to **std::set** via lambda results in a sorted list by **containerPtrs[n]->m_pPlugin->m_loadPriority**.
Another range loop iterates over **containerPtrs** and calls **containerPtrs[n]->m_pPlugin->Initialize(...)** on each element.
Then a quick **std::erase/remove** clears all the lements that failed to initialize by checking **containerPtrs[n]->m_bFailedInit**

## [Details (Unload)]
Again a temp vector **containerPtrs** is created.
Another range loop copies pointers to eachelement as before.
Now a **std::reverse** initially reverses the entire vector.
Then a quick sort (reverse of load sort) sorts everything by **containerPtrs[n]->m_pPlugin->m_unloadPriority**.

## [Modifications]
Had to modify Cryengine Plugins to include the necessary priorities in their plugin constructors.
Modified **SPluginContainer** to set **m_bFailedInit** on failed Initialization/null plugin ptr.
Specifically modified Schematyc plugins for special unload priorities. (this finally fixed my exit crash :P)
Also had to move intialization of **STDEnv** member pointers such as **m_pSystemStateMonitor** into the Initialize method.^^

^^ - The constructors in these classes assume Core is already Initalized. True in the default implementation as Init follows immediately after Instantiation.

## [Use Notes]
There is a new enum in **ICryPlugin** to help clarify and provide flexibility with priorities.
```	enum EPluginPriority : int16
	{
		EPluginPriority_CryUnload = -100,	// Lowest priority
		EPluginPriority_Default = 0,
		EPluginPriority_CryLoad = 100	// Highest priority
	};
```

All you have to do is put this in your plugin (**ICryPlugin** Inheritor) constructor:
```	m_loadPriority = EPluginPriority_Default;
	m_unloadPriority = EPluginPriority_Default;
```
	
Then in another plugin you can (un)load in you desired order:
```	m_loadPriority = EPluginPriority_Default-1; // Lower priority
	m_unloadPriority = EPluginPriority_Default+1; // Higher priority
```

----
It feels hackish ha, but I dunno gives a bit of freedom. Only reason I had to do this is because I didn't want to chase invalidated virtual pointers because schematyc unload wasnt just so xD. Maybe unnecessary in future builds anyway.
